title: What's the English translation of 肉麻的? - Quora

response.answer_text: As with all such questions, the first answer is, "There is no single translation," since any and all choices will be context-dependent.  Generally speaking, 肉麻 describes a reaction to a public display that crosses the bounds of taste into tackiness. If you were to hear a guy call his girlfriend "Snookums," or something similarly cute without being ironic, the shudder that might give you would be 肉麻. It's the same reaction northern Chinese get when they hear Taiwanese boys talk. Similarly, Hello Kitty - bordered booth photos of dippy girls puffing their cheeks out and V-signing is also 肉麻. Oh, gross. It makes my flesh creep.  "Makes my flesh creep" is close to 肉麻's literal meaning, but again, context will determine whether or not you're using it accurately or as a false positive. The English term can describe reactions of visceral disgust as opposed to derision, such as the sight of an opened corpse, and may thereby take the English in a direction you don't want it to go.

It depends on the sentence. Some possibilities are: nauseating, sickening, or disgusting. If you're describing something that's overly emotional or sentimental you might use: cheesy, corny, or mawkish. This is a very useful tool for finding example sentences.http://www.jukuu.com/search.php?q=肉麻的
